marketNews.title: RI Inflation Rises to 2.75% Amid Soaring Rice Prices
marketNews.content: BPS (Central Bureau of Statistics) recorded that the Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation in Indonesia in February 2024 rose to 2.75% YoY (vs. January 2024: 2.57% YoY), exceeding the consensus expectation of 2.6% YoY and marking the highest level since November 2023. The increase in inflation in February 2024 was driven by the rise in basic food prices, such as rice prices which increased by +5.32% MoM and +19.28% YoY. The surge in rice prices occurred amid an increase in paddy field prices at the farmer level. BPS noted that the price of main harvest dry paddy increased by +4.86% MoM and +27.14% YoY in February 2024, while the price of milled dry paddy increased by +6.13% MoM and +33.48% YoY. Besides rice, the Deputy for Production Statistics at BPS, M. Habibullah, stated that the prices of chicken meat, chili, and sugar were also the largest contributors to inflation in February 2024. According to an economist at Bank Danamon Indonesia, Irman Faiz, the rise in food prices in February 2024 was also driven by seasonal patterns ahead of Ramadan. On a monthly basis, CPI inflation reached 0.37% MoM in February 2024 (vs. January 2024: 0.04% MoM). Meanwhile, core inflation in February 2024 was 1.68% YoY (vs. expectation: 1.71% YoY), stable compared to the previous month and marking the lowest level since December 2021. Since the beginning of the year, CPI inflation in Indonesia reached 0.34% YTD as of February 2024. Bank Indonesia targets inflation in 2024 to be in the range of 1.5-3.5%. Key Takeaway: The Government expects rice prices to start falling following additional supply from the increase in the rice import quota from 2 million tons to 3.6 million tons in 2024, as well as the entry of the main harvest season which falls in March 2024. Successfully controlling rice prices to a more normal level will reduce the burden on inflation. On the other hand, if rice prices remain high, this has the potential to suppress public purchasing power, negatively impacting consumer sector issuers, especially those targeting the lower-middle segment.

tickerNews.title: ADRO: FY23 Net Profit -34.2% YoY, but Exceeds Expectations
tickerNews.content: Adaro Energy Indonesia recorded a net profit of 1.64 billion US dollars (-34.2% YoY) in 2023, equivalent to 110% of estimates and exceeding consensus. Revenue decreased by -19.6% YoY to 6.5 billion US dollars, but still exceeded (104%) estimates. The decline in revenue was caused by a decrease in ASP of -26% YoY. Meanwhile, coal sales volume grew by +7% YoY to 65.71 million tons. In terms of operations, production volume in 2023 increased by +4.8% YoY to 65.88 million tons, with the strip ratio rising to 4.35x (vs. 2022: 3.75x).

tickerNews.title: ADMR: FY23 Net Profit $441 Million (+33.8% YoY), Exceeding Consensus Estimates
tickerNews.content: Adaro Minerals Indonesia recorded a net profit of 441 million US dollars (+33.8% YoY) in 2023, exceeding (127%) consensus estimates. Revenue grew by +19.6% YoY to 1.1 billion US dollars (109% of estimates), supported by coal sales volume growth of +39.4% YoY which compensated for the ASP decrease of -14% YoY. In terms of operations, production volume in 2023 increased by +52% YoY to 5.11 million tons. Meanwhile, the strip ratio increased to 3.66x (vs. 2022: 2.47x).

tickerNews.title: PGEO: FY23 Net Profit $163.6 Million (+28.5% YoY), Exceeding Consensus Expectations
tickerNews.content: Pertamina Geothermal Energy recorded a net profit of 163.6 million US dollars (+28.5% YoY) in 2023, equivalent to 109% of estimates and exceeding consensus expectations. This result was driven by revenue growth of +5.2% YoY to 406.3 million US dollars (101% of estimates) derived from all operating areas such as Kamojang (+3.8% YoY), Ulubelu (+7.2% YoY), and Lumut Balai (+8.7% YoY). PGEO's net profit growth was also supported by a more moderate increase in cost of revenue (+3.3% YoY), followed by significant increases in financial income (+1,744% YoY) and other income (+190% YoY).

tickerNews.title: ELSA: FY23 Net Profit IDR 503.1 Billion (+33.1% YoY), Below Consensus Expectations
tickerNews.content: Elnusa recorded a net profit of 503.1 billion Rupiah (+33.1% YoY) in 2023, equivalent to 90% of estimates or lower than consensus expectations. This result was driven by revenue growth of +2.1% YoY to 12.6 trillion Rupiah, mainly supported by the growth in oil and gas support services of +39.2% YoY to 1.4 trillion Rupiah (105% of estimates). Meanwhile, the cost of revenue remained stable.

tickerNews.title: PANI: FY23 Net Profit IDR 270 Billion (+95.4% YoY)
tickerNews.content: Pantai Indah Kapuk Dua recorded a net profit of 270 billion Rupiah (+95.4% YoY) in 2023. This result was supported by revenue growth of +273.7% YoY to 2.2 trillion Rupiah, while the cost of revenue increased by +500.9% YoY to 1.1 trillion Rupiah.

tickerNews.title: JPFA: FY23 Net Profit Decreased by -31% YoY, Below Consensus Expectations
tickerNews.content: Japfa Comfeed Indonesia recorded a net profit decrease of -31% YoY to 930 billion Rupiah in 2023, equivalent to 80% of estimates or lower than consensus expectations. This result was suppressed by rising operating expenses of +7% YoY to 5.2 trillion Rupiah, while revenue only grew by +5% YoY to 51 trillion Rupiah (101% of estimates), causing the net profit margin to drop to 1.8% (vs. 2022: 2.9%).

tickerNews.title: Various Updates: Tourist Arrivals, Deposit Insurance Corporation Policy, HEAL's Capex for Expansion, and Constitutional Court Ruling on Parliamentary Threshold
tickerNews.content: BPS recorded that foreign tourist arrivals to Indonesia in January 2024 reached 927.75 thousand (-18.7% MoM, +16.19% YoY). The government targets 17 million foreign tourist arrivals in 2024. The Head of the Board of Commissioners of the Deposit Insurance Corporation (LPS), Purbaya Yudhi Sadewa, stated that LPS will launch the Policy Guarantee Institution (LPP) in 2028. Currently, LPS is still discussing with industry players, OJK, and the Ministry of Finance to determine the appropriate form for the LPP program. Purbaya explained that insurance companies joining the LPP will have their risk-based capital measured. The Finance Director of Medikaloka Hermina (HEAL), Yulisar Khiat, stated that the company targets revenue growth of +16.8% in 2024. To achieve this target, HEAL allocated a capex of 2 trillion Rupiah in 2024. These funds are intended for building 5 new hospitals in IKN, Madiun, Pasuruan, PIK 2, and Pekanbaru, bringing HEAL's total hospitals to 52 units by the end of 2024. Besides establishing new hospitals, Yulisar mentioned that the capex will also be used to increase the bed capacity at existing Hermina hospitals from 4,000 beds to 7,000 beds. On Thursday (29/2), the Constitutional Court abolished the parliamentary threshold provision of 4% of the national valid votes, deeming it inconsistent with the principle of people's sovereignty, electoral justice, and violating legal certainty guaranteed by the constitution. However, the abolition of the parliamentary threshold will not apply to the 2024 election, but rather to the 2029 election.
